natural problem: What is the 453rd digit to the right of the decimal point in the decimal expansion of $\frac{6}{13}$?
natural solution: The decimal representation of $\frac{6}{13}$ is $0.\overline{461538}$, which repeats every 6 digits. Since 453 divided by 6 has a remainder of 3, the 453rd digit is the same as the third digit after the decimal point, which is $\boxed{1}$.

and h1 : "decimal_expansion (6 / 13) n = 1"

 *)

fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 453"
and h1 : "decimal_expansion (6 / 13) n = 1"

 proof-

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 453"
and h1 : "real_of_rat (6 / 13) = sum (\<lambda>i. (1 / 10) ^ Suc i * (1 mod 10)) {..n} + 
            (1 / 10) ^ Suc n * real_of_int (1 div 10 ^ (n mod 10))"
shows  "1 div 10 ^ (n mod 10) = 1"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the 453rd digit to the right of the decimal point in the decimal expansion of $\frac{6}{13}$? The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 The decimal representation of $\frac{6}{13}$ is $0.\overline{461538}$, which repeats every 6 digits. Since 453 divided by 6 has a remainder of 3, the 453rd digit is the same as the third digit after the decimal point, which is $\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 453"
and h1 : "real_of_rat (6 / 13) = sum (\<lambda>i. (1 / 10) ^ Suc i * (1 mod 10)) {..n} + 
            (1 / 10) ^ Suc n * real_of_int (1 div 10 ^ (n mod 10))"
shows  "1 div 10 ^ (n mod 10) = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given that $n = 453$ and $\frac{6}{13} = \sum_{i=0}^{n} \left(\frac{1}{10}\right)^{i+1} * (1 \mod 10) + \left(\frac{1}{10}\right)^{n+1} * \frac{1}{10^{n \mod 10}}$, find the value of $\frac{1}{10^{n \mod 10}}$. The final answer is $1$.

 *)
